name: Atherectomy
description: Endovascular technique for debulking atherosclerotic plaque using specialized devices that mechanically remove or modify plaque rather than simply displacing it. Particularly useful for heavily calcified lesions and in-stent restenosis.

directional_atherectomy.mechanism: Rotating blade cuts and collects plaque into nose cone
directional_atherectomy.advantages: Removes plaque for histology, effective for eccentric lesions

orbital_atherectomy.mechanism: Diamond-coated crown orbits at high speed, sanding calcium
orbital_atherectomy.advantages: Differential cutting (preferential on hard plaque), vessel compliance
orbital_atherectomy.disadvantages: Slow debris, requires blood flow for cooling

laser_atherectomy.advantages: Useful for in-stent restenosis, chronic total occlusions

primary: Heavily calcified lesions not amenable to balloon alone
indications.vessel_preparation: Modify calcium to allow balloon expansion and drug delivery

technique.wire: Must have wire across lesion before atherectomy
technique.device_selection: Based on lesion morphology, calcification, vessel size
technique.passes: Multiple passes may be required for adequate debulking
technique.adjunctive: Often followed by balloon angioplasty ± DCB ± stent

complications.dissection: Similar to balloon, may require stenting

outcomes.patency: Variable based on lesion type and adjunctive therapy
outcomes.dcb_combination: Atherectomy + DCB may improve outcomes in calcified lesions
outcomes.no_stent_approach: Leave nothing behind philosophy for femoropopliteal

clinical_pearls: Atherectomy is a VESSEL PREPARATION tool - usually followed by balloon/DCB
Orbital works best on calcium (differential cutting on hard tissue)
CFA lesions ideal for atherectomy - avoid stenting in groin
Embolization is the main risk - consider embolic protection
learning_objectives: Compare different atherectomy mechanisms and their indications
Identify complications of atherectomy and their management
Explain the role of atherectomy as vessel preparation for adjunctive therapy

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
